chunks.title: Section 359 IPC - Kidnapping
chunks.content: Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship.

chunks.title: Section 362 IPC - Abduction
chunks.content: Whoever by force compels, or by deceitful means induces any person to go from any place, is said to abduct that person.
chunks.summary: Defines abduction as forceful or deceitful inducement to move.

chunks.title: Nature of Offence
chunks.content: The offence under Section 359-374 IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.
chunks.summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.

chunks.title: Bailability
chunks.content: Section 359-374 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

chunks.title: Trial Jurisdiction
chunks.content: Due to seriousness, Section 359-374 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

chunks.title: Witness Testimony
chunks.content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.
chunks.summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.

chunks.title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
chunks.content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause of death, or identity of accused.
chunks.summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.

chunks.title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
chunks.content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) together to establish liability.
chunks.summary: Both mental and physical elements required.

chunks.case_name: Sham Singh v. State of Haryana
Lallu Manjhi v. State of Jharkhand

chunks.question: What is the punishment under Section 359-374 IPC?
chunks.answer: Punishment includes imprisonment and/or fine as provided by law.

chunks.question: Is Section 359-374 a bailable offence?
chunks.answer: No, it is generally non-bailable.

chunks.question: Is Section 359-374 a cognizable offence?
chunks.answer: Yes, police may register FIR and investigate without magistrate approval.

chunks.question: What is kidnapping as per Section 359 IPC?
chunks.answer: Kidnapping means taking away a person by force, deceit, or without consent from lawful guardianship.

chunks.question: What is abduction under Section 362 IPC?
chunks.answer: Abduction is the removal of a person by force or compulsion, usually for an illegal purpose.

chunks.question: Can kidnapping be compoundable under IPC?
chunks.answer: No, kidnapping offences under IPC are not compoundable.

chunks.question: What is the maximum punishment for kidnapping for ransom under Section 364A IPC?
chunks.answer: Maximum punishment is death penalty or life imprisonment and fine.

chunks.question: What is the difference between kidnapping and abduction under IPC?
chunks.answer: Kidnapping is an offence per se, requiring taking away without consent; abduction requires a criminal intent and is punishable only when done for specific purposes.

chunks.question: Is intention necessary for kidnapping under IPC?
chunks.answer: Intention is not required for the basic offence of kidnapping, but it is for aggravated forms like ransom or exploitation.

chunks.question: Can a minor be prosecuted for kidnapping or abduction?
chunks.answer: Yes, but proceedings are conducted under the Juvenile Justice Act if the accused is under 18.

chunks.question: Which court tries kidnapping/abduction cases under IPC?
chunks.answer: Usually tried by Sessions Court, especially for serious offences.

chunks.question: Can abetment of kidnapping/abduction be punished?
chunks.answer: Yes, abetment is punishable under relevant provisions such as Sections 107/108 IPC.

chunks.question: Does conviction for kidnapping affect government employment?
chunks.answer: Yes, conviction for kidnapping/abduction generally bars an individual from government service.

chunks.question: Can a conviction for kidnapping/abduction be appealed?
chunks.answer: Yes, a convicted person may appeal in High Court and Supreme Court.

chunks.question: Are there any common defences against kidnapping charges?
chunks.answer: Absence of intention, consent of the person taken, mistaken identity or lack of guardianship may be used as defence.

chunks.question: Is there any limitation period for trial under Section 359-374 IPC?
chunks.answer: No, serious offences such as kidnapping have no limitation period for prosecution.

chunks.question: Is medical evidence required in kidnapping/abduction cases?
chunks.answer: Medical evidence is relevant if there are physical injuries, otherwise witness testimonies are primary.

chunks.question: What recent trends are emerging in prosecution of kidnapping/abduction?
chunks.answer: Recent trends include use of electronic evidence, tracking mobile devices, and emphasis on quick rescue and rehabilitation of victims.

chunks.question: Are offences under IPC 359-374 compoundable if victim returns home?
chunks.answer: No, return of the victim does not compound the offence; prosecution proceeds as per law.

chunks.question: Is police complaint necessary for starting proceedings under Section 359-374 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, police complaint (FIR) initiates investigation in kidnapping/abduction cases under IPC.
